text: Q: Hello, Oda Sensei! Luffy's catchphrase is, "I'm going to be the Pirate King!" But in the original Japanese, it's put in a distinctly different order, like, "The Pirate King is what I'll be!" Is there some reason for reversing the normal way of writing this?

A: My goodness! This question? After 90 volumes?! I guess you got really curious. As a matter of fact, about 20 years ago, when the TV anime series was starting, the producer Mr. Shimizu from Toei Animation, whom I call "The Father of One Piece," asked me the same thing. The fact that I was so particular about this phrasing was a sign to Mr. Shimizu, and convinced him that One Piece was going to be a success!! And the reason for my particular obsession is...!!! To be continued (not). I just think it's a powerful statement, grammatically. If I was the kind of person who wrote it the standard way, I don't think I would've been able to depict Luffy the way he is! So the answer is: it was just on a whim!
Q: Heso! Here's my question. That pirate waiting for Zeff's cooking on the Baratie in chapter 902 looks a lot like Crescent Moon Gary from the "Romance Dawn" one-shot, doesn't he?
A: Very well spotted, very well sleuthed. That's right, this is a pirate who appears in the One Piece prototype one-shot, a fellow named Crescent Moon Gary. Brilliant work!

Q: I have a serious question for you, Odacchi. Does the fact that it's called "Pangaea" Castle in Mary Geoise mean that all of the continents of the world could fit together like a puzzle? Making them all...one piece? Pangaea Castle is located in the center of the world, so I think it makes sense.
A: The continent of Pangaea is the name of when all the continents of the world formed a single landmass eons ago. So why did I choose that name in particular...? I'm not saying. LOL!
